item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Correlation Between NMR Coupling Constants and σ‐Donating Properties of N‐Heterocyclic Carbenes and Their Derivatives
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A detailed comparison of σ‐donation indicators, including the calculated 1JC−H coupling constant, across a broad spectrum of diverse carbenes provides new insights into their strengths and limitations. This study highlights the utility of 1JC−H for assessing σ‐donation in structurally similar carbenes, while revealing its constraints for carbenes with significantly different frameworks, offering guidance for evaluating electronic properties.
Abstract Is the 1JC−H coupling constant for protonated carbene a relevant measure of its σ‐donation ability? This paper addresses this question by comparing calculated 1JC−H values with various experimental and theoretical approaches across a broad spectrum of carbene compounds. We examined Arduengo‐type NHCs based on the 2‐imidazolylidene scaffold and many other derivatives with modified frameworks, including carbenes with extended, saturated, or conjugated rings, reduced heteroatom stabilization, alternative heteroatoms, permanently charged carbenes, acyclic carbenes, amidocarbenes, and cyclic amino(alkyl/aryl) carbenes, carbodicarbenes and carbodiphosphoranes. Our findings reveal a nuanced relationship between different parameters associated with σ‐interaction, such as 1JC−H, Huynh electronic parameter (HEP), σ‐donation from ETS‐NOCV, and lone pair energy. Notably, the best correlation was observed between 1JC−H and the ETS‐NOCV method, particularly for mono‐ and diaminocarbenes, highlighting the utility of 1JC−H in comparing σ‐donation among structurally similar carbene types. However, the use of 1JC−H as a universal measure across all carbene classes appears limited, especially when considering carbenes with significantly different structural frameworks. While HEP is less effective for carbenes with diverse structural backbones, our study suggests that 1JC−H has potential across a broader range of systems. Additionally, the analysis demonstrates that lone pair energy reflects basicity rather than σ‐donor ability.
item.content:encoded:
A detailed comparison of σ-donation indicators, including the calculated 1 J C−H coupling constant, across a broad spectrum of diverse carbenes provides new insights into their strengths and limitations. This study highlights the utility of 1 J C−H for assessing σ-donation in structurally similar carbenes, while revealing its constraints for carbenes with significantly different frameworks, offering guidance for evaluating electronic properties.


Abstract

Is the 1 J C−H coupling constant for protonated carbene a relevant measure of its σ-donation ability? This paper addresses this question by comparing calculated 1 J C−H values with various experimental and theoretical approaches across a broad spectrum of carbene compounds. We examined Arduengo-type NHCs based on the 2-imidazolylidene scaffold and many other derivatives with modified frameworks, including carbenes with extended, saturated, or conjugated rings, reduced heteroatom stabilization, alternative heteroatoms, permanently charged carbenes, acyclic carbenes, amidocarbenes, and cyclic amino(alkyl/aryl) carbenes, carbodicarbenes and carbodiphosphoranes. Our findings reveal a nuanced relationship between different parameters associated with σ-interaction, such as 1 J C−H , Huynh electronic parameter (HEP), σ-donation from ETS-NOCV, and lone pair energy. Notably, the best correlation was observed between 1 J C−H and the ETS-NOCV method, particularly for mono- and diaminocarbenes, highlighting the utility of 1 J C−H in comparing σ-donation among structurally similar carbene types. However, the use of 1 J C−H as a universal measure across all carbene classes appears limited, especially when considering carbenes with significantly different structural frameworks. While HEP is less effective for carbenes with diverse structural backbones, our study suggests that 1 J C−H has potential across a broader range of systems. Additionally, the analysis demonstrates that lone pair energy reflects basicity rather than σ-donor ability.

item.dc:title: Correlation Between NMR Coupling Constants and σ‐Donating Properties of N‐Heterocyclic Carbenes and Their Derivatives

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Tuning of a Hydrogen‐Bonded Organic Framework by Liquid‐Assisted Mechanosynthesis between Trans‐Aconitic Acid and Isonicotinamide
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A novel hydrogen‐bonded organic framework (HOF) system was developed using trans‐aconitic acid and isonicotinamide via mechanochemical milling. The crystal structures were determined by SCXRD, microcrystal electron diffraction and synchrotron X‐ray diffraction. PXRD verified the isostructurality, thermogravimetric analysis confirmed their stability and this study also showcase tunable HOF properties.
Abstract Cocrystallization of trans‐aconitic acid (TACA) and isonicotinamide (INA) using liquid assisted mechanochemical grinding results in a unique supramolecular hydrogen‐bonded organic framework (HOF) system encapsulating various organic solvents (liquid guest) with the formation of channel inclusion compounds. Dimension and shape of the framework is dependent on the solvent used during liquid assisted grinding (LAG). Although crystal structure of the cocrystal (TACA) ⋅ (INA)2 ⋅ (H2O)@(INA)0.5 has been determined by Single Crystal X‐ray diffraction (SCXRD), crystal structures of 3 cocrystal HOFs were determined by microcrystal electron diffraction (MicroED) and synchrotron X‐ray diffraction due to lack of suitable single crystal. PXRD analysis confirms isostructurality of various host‐guest systems; whereas guest incorporation as well as stability of the HOFs were further confirmed using thermogravimetric analysis. This study demonstrates that the framework of HOFs can be tuned by varying solvent molecules used during LAG.
item.content:encoded:
A novel hydrogen-bonded organic framework (HOF) system was developed using trans-aconitic acid and isonicotinamide via mechanochemical milling. The crystal structures were determined by SCXRD, microcrystal electron diffraction and synchrotron X-ray diffraction. PXRD verified the isostructurality, thermogravimetric analysis confirmed their stability and this study also showcase tunable HOF properties.


Abstract

Cocrystallization of trans-aconitic acid (TACA) and isonicotinamide (INA) using liquid assisted mechanochemical grinding results in a unique supramolecular hydrogen-bonded organic framework (HOF) system encapsulating various organic solvents (liquid guest) with the formation of channel inclusion compounds. Dimension and shape of the framework is dependent on the solvent used during liquid assisted grinding (LAG). Although crystal structure of the cocrystal (TACA) ⋅ (INA)2 ⋅ (H2O)@(INA)0.5 has been determined by Single Crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), crystal structures of 3 cocrystal HOFs were determined by microcrystal electron diffraction (MicroED) and synchrotron X-ray diffraction due to lack of suitable single crystal. PXRD analysis confirms isostructurality of various host-guest systems; whereas guest incorporation as well as stability of the HOFs were further confirmed using thermogravimetric analysis. This study demonstrates that the framework of HOFs can be tuned by varying solvent molecules used during LAG.
item.dc:creator: Diptajyoti Gogoi, Toshiyuki Sasaki, Nabadeep Kalita, Tapaswini Sethi, Kouhei Ichiyanagi, Takanori Nakane, Akihiro Kawamoto, Dinabandhu Das, Genji Kurisu, Ranjit Thakuria
item.dc:title: Tuning of a Hydrogen‐Bonded Organic Framework by Liquid‐Assisted Mechanosynthesis between Trans‐Aconitic Acid and Isonicotinamide

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Liquid‐Crystallization‐Driven Self‐Assembly toward Uniform Multi‐Morphology Fried‐Egg‐Like Nanostructures
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
By liquid‐crystallization‐driven self‐assembly (LCDSA) of copolymers consisting of star‐like PAMAM and chain termini of liquid crystalline Azo units (PAMAM‐Azo6), uniform multi‐morphology fried‐egg‐like micelles containing an inner spherical/bowl‐like core and platelet‐like structure protruded for the core can be generated. It is found that the aggregation rate of PAMAM‐Azo6 is one of the most important factors determining LCDSA behavior and morphology of formed micelles.
Abstract Liquid‐crystallization‐driven self‐assembly (LCDSA) has recently emerged as an efficient strategy to create uniform one‐dimensional (1‐D), 2‐D and 3‐D nanostructures in a controlled manner. However, the examples of generation of uniform multi‐morphology nanostructures from solution self‐assembly of one single polymer sample are rare. Herein, we report the first example of preparation of multi‐morphology fried‐egg‐like nanostructures consisting of an inner spherical/bowl‐like core of uniform size and platelets protruded from the core by LCDSA of PAMAM‐Azo6 (PAMAM=polyamidoamine, Azo=azobenzene) in methanol. It is disclosed that the different aggregation rates for PAMAM‐Azo6 with varying contents of Azo units spontaneously separated nucleation and growth stages, which led to the formation of inner spherical/bowl‐like cores (“seeds”) firstly, followed by the formation of platelets protruded from the edges of inner core to give “imperfect” fried‐egg‐like nanostructures. Additional annealing of initially formed “imperfect” fried‐egg‐like micelles will promote the rearrangement of Azo units to give thermodynamically‐favored “perfect” fried‐egg‐shaped micelles with a uniform dimension both in the core and whole structure. This work not only provides an efficient strategy to create uniform multi‐morphology fried‐egg‐shaped nanostructures, but also reveals the essential impact of aggregation kinetics of liquid‐crystalline‐coil BCPs in the formation of multi‐morphology nanostructures.
item.content:encoded:
By liquid-crystallization-driven self-assembly (LCDSA) of copolymers consisting of star-like PAMAM and chain termini of liquid crystalline Azo units (PAMAM-Azo6), uniform multi-morphology fried-egg-like micelles containing an inner spherical/bowl-like core and platelet-like structure protruded for the core can be generated. It is found that the aggregation rate of PAMAM-Azo6 is one of the most important factors determining LCDSA behavior and morphology of formed micelles.


Abstract

Liquid-crystallization-driven self-assembly (LCDSA) has recently emerged as an efficient strategy to create uniform one-dimensional (1-D), 2-D and 3-D nanostructures in a controlled manner. However, the examples of generation of uniform multi-morphology nanostructures from solution self-assembly of one single polymer sample are rare. Herein, we report the first example of preparation of multi-morphology fried-egg-like nanostructures consisting of an inner spherical/bowl-like core of uniform size and platelets protruded from the core by LCDSA of PAMAM-Azo6 (PAMAM=polyamidoamine, Azo=azobenzene) in methanol. It is disclosed that the different aggregation rates for PAMAM-Azo6 with varying contents of Azo units spontaneously separated nucleation and growth stages, which led to the formation of inner spherical/bowl-like cores (“seeds”) firstly, followed by the formation of platelets protruded from the edges of inner core to give “imperfect” fried-egg-like nanostructures. Additional annealing of initially formed “imperfect” fried-egg-like micelles will promote the rearrangement of Azo units to give thermodynamically-favored “perfect” fried-egg-shaped micelles with a uniform dimension both in the core and whole structure. This work not only provides an efficient strategy to create uniform multi-morphology fried-egg-shaped nanostructures, but also reveals the essential impact of aggregation kinetics of liquid-crystalline-coil BCPs in the formation of multi-morphology nanostructures.

item.dc:title: Liquid‐Crystallization‐Driven Self‐Assembly toward Uniform Multi‐Morphology Fried‐Egg‐Like Nanostructures

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: A Strongly Coupled 1T’‐ReSe2@2H‐MoSe2 van der Waals Heterostructure for Efficient Electrocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution at High Current Densities
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A van der Waals heterostructure composed of 1T’‐ReSe2 and 2H‐MoSe2 exhibits exceptional catalytic capabilities in promoting the hydrogen evolution reaction, primarily attributed to the strong electronic interaction between 1T’‐ReSe2 and 2H‐MoSe2. Theoretical calculations indicate that hydrogen adsorption at the heterostructure exhibits an appropriate Gibbs free energy alteration conducive to the hydrogen evolution process.
Abstract Developing efficient and durable non‐noble metal electrocatalysts for high current‐density hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) is a pressing requirement for commercial industrial electrolyzers. In this study, a vertical 1T’‐ReSe2@2H‐MoSe2 van der Waals heterostructure was developed through interface engineering to enhance the advantages of each component and expose numerous active sites. Experimental investigations and density functional theory calculations demonstrate significant electronic coupling at the interface between 1T’‐ReSe2 and 2H‐MoSe2, with suitable Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption. The 1T’‐ReSe2@2H‐MoSe2 heterostructure catalyst achieves high current density HER with low overpotentials of 191 mV to generate up to 800 mA/cm2 in 0.5 M H2SO4, outperforming commercial 5 % Pt/C catalysts. Moreover, this catalyst exhibits rapid reaction kinetics and long‐term durability, illustrating a successful approach to designing efficient heterostructure electrocatalysts for hydrogen production through interface engineering.
item.content:encoded:
A van der Waals heterostructure composed of 1T’-ReSe2 and 2H-MoSe2 exhibits exceptional catalytic capabilities in promoting the hydrogen evolution reaction, primarily attributed to the strong electronic interaction between 1T’-ReSe2 and 2H-MoSe2. Theoretical calculations indicate that hydrogen adsorption at the heterostructure exhibits an appropriate Gibbs free energy alteration conducive to the hydrogen evolution process.


Abstract

Developing efficient and durable non-noble metal electrocatalysts for high current-density hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) is a pressing requirement for commercial industrial electrolyzers. In this study, a vertical 1T’-ReSe2@2H-MoSe2 van der Waals heterostructure was developed through interface engineering to enhance the advantages of each component and expose numerous active sites. Experimental investigations and density functional theory calculations demonstrate significant electronic coupling at the interface between 1T’-ReSe2 and 2H-MoSe2, with suitable Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption. The 1T’-ReSe2@2H-MoSe2 heterostructure catalyst achieves high current density HER with low overpotentials of 191 mV to generate up to 800 mA/cm2 in 0.5 M H2SO4, outperforming commercial 5 % Pt/C catalysts. Moreover, this catalyst exhibits rapid reaction kinetics and long-term durability, illustrating a successful approach to designing efficient heterostructure electrocatalysts for hydrogen production through interface engineering.
item.dc:creator: Xingchen Zhang, Dongfang Zhang, Dingyi Zhou, Xinya Chen, Jinying Zhang, Zhiyong Wang
item.dc:title: A Strongly Coupled 1T’‐ReSe2@2H‐MoSe2 van der Waals Heterostructure for Efficient Electrocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution at High Current Densities

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: One‐Step Hydrothermal Synthesis of Glucose‐Induced Low Crystallinity NiCo‐Based Layered Double Hydroxides for High‐Performance Asymmetric Supercapacitors
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Supercapacitor electrodes: Glucose induced NiCo‐based layered double hydroxides (NiCoLDH) to produce excellent electrode structure, thereby improving the electrochemical performance of supercapacitor.
Abstract In order to improve the electrochemical performance of NiCo‐based layered double hydroxide (NiCoLDH), the synthesis of low‐crystallinity NiCoLDH was induced by the adsorption of glucose and NiCoLDH. The results showed that glucose could not only effectively regulate the pore structure and morphology of NiCoLDH, but also had a regular effect on crystallinity. Pure phase NiCoLDH had higher crystallinity. When the mass of glucose is 0.05 g, the prepared NiCoLDH‐0.05 is a short‐range ordered structure embedded in the amorphous matrix. The crystallinity of the product decreases further with the further increase of glucose mass. Since the ordered structures have higher electrical conductivity, and amorphous structures have more defects and active sites, the structure of NiCoLDH‐0.05 is conducive to achieving the best electrochemical performance. Electrochemical test results show that NiCoLDH‐0.05 has a high specific capacitance, about 12 times that of the pure phase NiCoLDH, the mass of glucose is higher than or below 0.05 g, the specific capacitance will be further reduced. NiCoLDH‐0.05 and activated carbon assembled into an asymmetric supercapacitor have a power density of 400 W kg−1 at an energy density of 32.7 Wh kg−1. This study provides a new idea for obtaining excellent electrochemical properties by adjusting LDH crystallinity.
item.content:encoded:
Supercapacitor electrodes: Glucose induced NiCo-based layered double hydroxides (NiCoLDH) to produce excellent electrode structure, thereby improving the electrochemical performance of supercapacitor.


Abstract

In order to improve the electrochemical performance of NiCo-based layered double hydroxide (NiCoLDH), the synthesis of low-crystallinity NiCoLDH was induced by the adsorption of glucose and NiCoLDH. The results showed that glucose could not only effectively regulate the pore structure and morphology of NiCoLDH, but also had a regular effect on crystallinity. Pure phase NiCoLDH had higher crystallinity. When the mass of glucose is 0.05 g, the prepared NiCoLDH-0.05 is a short-range ordered structure embedded in the amorphous matrix. The crystallinity of the product decreases further with the further increase of glucose mass. Since the ordered structures have higher electrical conductivity, and amorphous structures have more defects and active sites, the structure of NiCoLDH-0.05 is conducive to achieving the best electrochemical performance. Electrochemical test results show that NiCoLDH-0.05 has a high specific capacitance, about 12 times that of the pure phase NiCoLDH, the mass of glucose is higher than or below 0.05 g, the specific capacitance will be further reduced. NiCoLDH-0.05 and activated carbon assembled into an asymmetric supercapacitor have a power density of 400 W kg−1 at an energy density of 32.7 Wh kg−1. This study provides a new idea for obtaining excellent electrochemical properties by adjusting LDH crystallinity.
item.dc:creator: Xiaoyang Cheng, Lihua Zhang, Lingyan Li, Hao Wu, Jinfeng Zheng, Jiao Sun, Guifang Li
item.dc:title: One‐Step Hydrothermal Synthesis of Glucose‐Induced Low Crystallinity NiCo‐Based Layered Double Hydroxides for High‐Performance Asymmetric Supercapacitors

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Tuning Tetramethoxy‐acridiniums for Fluorophores and Organic Photoredox Catalysis
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Non‐fluorescent tetramethoxy‐acridinium (TMAcr+) become fluorescent when substituted with electron withdrawing groups, due to inhibition of intramolecular PET quenching. Fluorescence quantum yield up to φf=20 % and a long fluorescence lifetime of τf=9 ns in CH2Cl2 are obtained. The TMAcr+ can be used as photooxidants due to their excited state reduction potentials (E*red=1.6 V vs. SCE).
Abstract Tetramethoxy substituted alkyl‐acridiniums (TMAcr+) are readily available by facile nucleophilic aromatic substitution on tris(2,6‐dimethoxyphenyl)carbenium, but are non‐fluorescent, presumably due to intramolecular photoinduced electron transfer quenching. In this work we introduce electron withdrawing groups by electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions, leading to fluorescence turn‐on. The acridiniums are moderately fluorescent (φf=20 %) with long fluorescene lifetimes (τf=9 ns). The positive excited state reduction potentials (E*red=+1.6 V) make the TMAcr+ excellent electron acceptors in the excited state, and efficient reductive photoredox catalysts able to oxidize a broad range of substrates.
item.content:encoded:
Non-fluorescent tetramethoxy-acridinium (TMAcr+) become fluorescent when substituted with electron withdrawing groups, due to inhibition of intramolecular PET quenching. Fluorescence quantum yield up to φf=20 % and a long fluorescence lifetime of τf=9 ns in CH2Cl2 are obtained. The TMAcr+ can be used as photooxidants due to their excited state reduction potentials (E*red=1.6 V vs. SCE).


Abstract

Tetramethoxy substituted alkyl-acridiniums (TMAcr+) are readily available by facile nucleophilic aromatic substitution on tris(2,6-dimethoxyphenyl)carbenium, but are non-fluorescent, presumably due to intramolecular photoinduced electron transfer quenching. In this work we introduce electron withdrawing groups by electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions, leading to fluorescence turn-on. The acridiniums are moderately fluorescent (φf=20 %) with long fluorescene lifetimes (τf=9 ns). The positive excited state reduction potentials (E*red=+1.6 V) make the TMAcr+ excellent electron acceptors in the excited state, and efficient reductive photoredox catalysts able to oxidize a broad range of substrates.
item.dc:creator: Marko H. Nowack, Magnus B. Johansen, Søren Sams, Andreas E. Hillers‐Bendtsen, Kurt V. Mikkelsen, Bo W. Laursen
item.dc:title: Tuning Tetramethoxy‐acridiniums for Fluorophores and Organic Photoredox Catalysis

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: A Nanosized {NiII18} Cluster with a ‘Flying Saucer’ Topology Exhibiting Slow Relaxation of Magnetisation Phenomena at Both 15 K and 1.3 K
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A high‐nuclearity {Ni18} nanosized complex with an unprecedented ‘flying saucer’ motif has been prepared from the organic chelate α‐methyl‐2‐pyridine‐methanol (mpmH) in conjunction with bridging azido and peroxido groups. The {Ni18} compound behaves as single‐molecule magnet and exhibits very rare two relaxation processes at 15 and 1.3 K.
Abstract A high‐nuclearity {Ni18} complex (1) with a unique ‘flying saucer’ motif has been prepared from the organic chelate, α‐methyl‐2‐pyridine‐methanol (mpmH), in conjunction with bridging azido (N3−) and peroxido (O22−) ligands. Magnetic susceptibility measurements revealed the presence of both ferro‐ and antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the metal centres in 1, and the stabilization of spin states with appreciable S values at two different temperature regimes. The end‐on bridging azido and alkoxido groups are in all likelihood the ferromagnetic mediators, while the η3:η3:μ6‐bridging peroxides most likely promote the antiparallel alignment of the metals’ spin vectors, yielding an overall non‐zero spin ground state for the centrosymmetric compound 1. Furthermore, the {Ni18} nanosized cluster behaves as a single‐molecule magnet, exhibiting magnetic hysteresis at low temperatures and two relaxation processes at 15 K and 1.3 K, a very rare phenomenon in polynuclear magnetic 3d‐metal clusters.
item.content:encoded:
A high-nuclearity {Ni18} nanosized complex with an unprecedented ‘flying saucer’ motif has been prepared from the organic chelate α-methyl-2-pyridine-methanol (mpmH) in conjunction with bridging azido and peroxido groups. The {Ni18} compound behaves as single-molecule magnet and exhibits very rare two relaxation processes at 15 and 1.3 K.


Abstract

A high-nuclearity {Ni18} complex (1) with a unique ‘flying saucer’ motif has been prepared from the organic chelate, α-methyl-2-pyridine-methanol (mpmH), in conjunction with bridging azido (N3 −) and peroxido (O2 2−) ligands. Magnetic susceptibility measurements revealed the presence of both ferro- and antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the metal centres in 1, and the stabilization of spin states with appreciable S values at two different temperature regimes. The end-on bridging azido and alkoxido groups are in all likelihood the ferromagnetic mediators, while the η3:η3:μ6-bridging peroxides most likely promote the antiparallel alignment of the metals’ spin vectors, yielding an overall non-zero spin ground state for the centrosymmetric compound 1. Furthermore, the {Ni18} nanosized cluster behaves as a single-molecule magnet, exhibiting magnetic hysteresis at low temperatures and two relaxation processes at 15 K and 1.3 K, a very rare phenomenon in polynuclear magnetic 3d-metal clusters.
item.dc:creator: Angeliki A. Athanasopoulou, Parisa Abbasi, Dimitris I. Alexandropoulos, John J. Hayward, Christine M. Beavers, Simon J. Teat, Wolfgang Wernsdorfer, Júlia Mayans, Albert Escuer, Melanie Pilkington, Theocharis C. Stamatatos
item.dc:title: A Nanosized {NiII18} Cluster with a ‘Flying Saucer’ Topology Exhibiting Slow Relaxation of Magnetisation Phenomena at Both 15 K and 1.3 K

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Translating Solid‐Phase Conformational Memory in the Prophecy of Multi‐stimuli Responsive Low Molecular Weight Gels
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Introducing flexible non‐polar functional groups, a bis‐urea based low molecular weight organogelator is synthesized. Three distinct polymorphic crystalline phases of the gelator were isolated with noticeable solubility differences. Different stimuli like heat‐cool, sonication, shaking, grinding showed varied gelling performances among the polymorphic phases further corroborated with their solubility parameter in the respective gelling solvents.
Abstract Polymorphism and its screening to select the best‐performing form is in high demand. In low molecular weight organogels (LMWG), gelators are designed as they contain flexible groups, functionalities capable of varied H‐bonding, and increased the potential to show polymorphism. We synthesized a bis‐urea based LMWG G1 and isolated three distinct polymorphic phases (Form I, II, and III). G1 polymorphs showed noticeable differences in solubility; precisely, Form I is highly soluble compared to the other two. Gel screening was carried out for all three polymorphs using different stimuli like heat‐cool, sonication, shaking, and grinding. Among the polymorphs, Form I was found to have better gelling ability which was reflected by the solvent scope, thermal stability (gel‐sol transition temperature Tgel), minimum gelator concentration (M.G.C.), stimuli‐responsiveness, morphology, and rheological properties. The differences in their gelation performance among the three polymorphs are associated with their solubility parameter. Stimuli like sonication, shaking, and grinding triggered Form I to form a gel. Form II and III responded to heat‐cool stimuli only due to poor solubility. Therefore, it is noted crucial to add polymorph screening as an integral part of the gel synthesis to avoid problems associated with reproducibility in the gel prophecy of LMWG systems.
item.content:encoded:
Introducing flexible non-polar functional groups, a bis-urea based low molecular weight organogelator is synthesized. Three distinct polymorphic crystalline phases of the gelator were isolated with noticeable solubility differences. Different stimuli like heat-cool, sonication, shaking, grinding showed varied gelling performances among the polymorphic phases further corroborated with their solubility parameter in the respective gelling solvents.


Abstract

Polymorphism and its screening to select the best-performing form is in high demand. In low molecular weight organogels (LMWG), gelators are designed as they contain flexible groups, functionalities capable of varied H-bonding, and increased the potential to show polymorphism. We synthesized a bis-urea based LMWG G1 and isolated three distinct polymorphic phases (Form I, II, and III). G1 polymorphs showed noticeable differences in solubility; precisely, Form I is highly soluble compared to the other two. Gel screening was carried out for all three polymorphs using different stimuli like heat-cool, sonication, shaking, and grinding. Among the polymorphs, Form I was found to have better gelling ability which was reflected by the solvent scope, thermal stability (gel-sol transition temperature Tgel), minimum gelator concentration (M.G.C.), stimuli-responsiveness, morphology, and rheological properties. The differences in their gelation performance among the three polymorphs are associated with their solubility parameter. Stimuli like sonication, shaking, and grinding triggered Form I to form a gel. Form II and III responded to heat-cool stimuli only due to poor solubility. Therefore, it is noted crucial to add polymorph screening as an integral part of the gel synthesis to avoid problems associated with reproducibility in the gel prophecy of LMWG systems.

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: A Cascade Synthesis of Furo‐Pyrrolo‐Pyridines via Pd(II)‐Catalyzed Dual N−H/C Annulative‐Cyclization
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A Pd(II)‐catalyzed non‐template synthesis of furo[2,3‐b]pyrrolo[2,3‐d]pyridines from β‐ketodinitriles and diynes has been accomplished via dual annulative cyclization. The participation of both the nitrile (−CN) groups led to the concurrent construction of three heterocycles viz. furan, pyrrole, and pyridine through forming C−C, C=C, C−O, C−N, and C=N bonds.
Abstract A Pd(II)‐catalyzed non‐template synthesis of furo[2,3‐b]pyrrolo[2,3‐d]pyridines from β‐ketodinitriles and buta‐1,3‐diynes has been accomplished via dual annulative cyclization. The participation of both the nitrile (−CN) groups led to the concurrent construction of three heterocycles viz. furan, pyrrole, and pyridine forming C−C, C=C, C−O, C−N, and C=N bonds in one pot. The synthetic utility of the protocol was further demonstrated through a few post‐synthetic manipulations.
item.content:encoded:
A Pd(II)-catalyzed non-template synthesis of furo[2,3-b]pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyridines from β-ketodinitriles and diynes has been accomplished via dual annulative cyclization. The participation of both the nitrile (−CN) groups led to the concurrent construction of three heterocycles viz. furan, pyrrole, and pyridine through forming C−C, C=C, C−O, C−N, and C=N bonds.


Abstract

A Pd(II)-catalyzed non-template synthesis of furo[2,3-b]pyrrolo[2,3-d]pyridines from β-ketodinitriles and buta-1,3-diynes has been accomplished via dual annulative cyclization. The participation of both the nitrile (−CN) groups led to the concurrent construction of three heterocycles viz. furan, pyrrole, and pyridine forming C−C, C=C, C−O, C−N, and C=N bonds in one pot. The synthetic utility of the protocol was further demonstrated through a few post-synthetic manipulations.
item.dc:creator: Hirendra Nath Dhara, Supriya Manna, Bhisma K. Patel
item.dc:title: A Cascade Synthesis of Furo‐Pyrrolo‐Pyridines via Pd(II)‐Catalyzed Dual N−H/C Annulative‐Cyclization

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Triarylmethanol Derivatives with Ultralong Organic Room‐Temperature Phosphorescence
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Triphenylmethanol derivatives have been shown to display ultra‐long phosphorescence and afterglow in both crystal and powder states in air at room temperature with afterglows of about 7 seconds, this material holds promise for static and dynamic anti‐counterfeiting applications.
Abstract Triphenylmethyl‐based compounds such as rhodamines and fluoresceine representing an old and well‐known class of triphenylmethane dyes, are widely used in fluorescent labeling of bioimaging. Inspired by ultralong room temperature phosphorescence of triphenylphosphine derivatives, herein we report a methoxy substituted triarylmethanol ((4‐methoxyphenyl)diphenylmethanol, LJW‐1) exhibits ultralong room temperature phosphorescence (RTP) under ambient condition with afterglows of about 7 seconds. Its multiple C−H ⋅ ⋅ ⋅ π intermolecular interactions, C−H ⋅ ⋅ ⋅ O intermolecular interactions, hydrogen bond and π‐π interactions are beneficial for forming rigid environment in the aggregated state which is evidently an important factor in the appearance of excellent RTP. Different substituents on triarylmethanol result in compounds with different lifetimes varying from 7 μs to 818 ms. The substituent effects on the phosphorescence of triarylmethanol derivatives provide an efficient method for the design of organic RTP materials and may be enlightening the phosphorescence research of triarylmethanol derivatives.
item.content:encoded:
Triphenylmethanol derivatives have been shown to display ultra-long phosphorescence and afterglow in both crystal and powder states in air at room temperature with afterglows of about 7 seconds, this material holds promise for static and dynamic anti-counterfeiting applications.


Abstract

Triphenylmethyl-based compounds such as rhodamines and fluoresceine representing an old and well-known class of triphenylmethane dyes, are widely used in fluorescent labeling of bioimaging. Inspired by ultralong room temperature phosphorescence of triphenylphosphine derivatives, herein we report a methoxy substituted triarylmethanol ((4-methoxyphenyl)diphenylmethanol, LJW-1) exhibits ultralong room temperature phosphorescence (RTP) under ambient condition with afterglows of about 7 seconds. Its multiple C−H ⋅ ⋅ ⋅ π intermolecular interactions, C−H ⋅ ⋅ ⋅ O intermolecular interactions, hydrogen bond and π-π interactions are beneficial for forming rigid environment in the aggregated state which is evidently an important factor in the appearance of excellent RTP. Different substituents on triarylmethanol result in compounds with different lifetimes varying from 7 μs to 818 ms. The substituent effects on the phosphorescence of triarylmethanol derivatives provide an efficient method for the design of organic RTP materials and may be enlightening the phosphorescence research of triarylmethanol derivatives.
item.dc:creator: Jinwei Li, Ruikang Duan, Yanmei Zhu, Mulin Chen, Xianyin Dai, Guiyun Duan, Yanqing Ge
item.dc:title: Triarylmethanol Derivatives with Ultralong Organic Room‐Temperature Phosphorescence

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Isoreticular Contraction in Dicopper Paddle‐Wheel‐Based Metal‐Organic Frameworks to Enhance C2H2/CO2 Separation
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Two isoreticualr MOFs of Cu‐TPTC and Cu‐ABTC were meticulously prepared. By strategically incorporating an azo group in place of a phenyl ring in the tetracarboxylate linker, Cu‐ABTC demonstrated a modest decrease in pore size while retaining high porosity relative to Cu‐TPTC. This modification led to a marked improvement in C2H2 adsorption capacity and C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity of Cu‐ABTC, along with an extended breakthrough time.
Abstract Achieving a balance between high selectivity and uptake is a formidable challenge for the purification of acetylene from mixtures with carbon dioxide, particularly when seeking to maximize both C2H2 adsorption capacity and C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity in crystalline porous materials. In this study, leveraging the principles of reticular chemistry, we selected two tetracarboxylate‐based linkers and combined them with Cu2+ ions to synthesize two isoreticular dicopper paddle‐wheel‐based metal‐organic frameworks (MOFs): Cu‐TPTC (terphenyl‐3,3’,5,5’‐tetracarboxylic acid, H4TPTC) and Cu‐ABTC (3,3,5,5‐azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid, H4ABTC). The structural and sorption analyses revealed that Cu‐ABTC, despite having slightly smaller pores due to the strategic replacement of a phenyl ring with an azo group between two tetratopic ligands, maintains high porosity compared to Cu‐TPTC. Furthermore, Cu‐ABTC outperforms Cu‐TPTC in terms of C2H2 adsorption capacity (196 cm3 g−1 at 298 K and 1 bar) and C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity (16.5~5.6). These findings were corroborated by dynamic breakthrough experiments and computational modeling. This research highlights the potential of the isoreticular contraction strategy in enhancing MOFs for sophisticated gas adsorption and separation processes.
item.content:encoded:
Two isoreticualr MOFs of Cu-TPTC and Cu-ABTC were meticulously prepared. By strategically incorporating an azo group in place of a phenyl ring in the tetracarboxylate linker, Cu-ABTC demonstrated a modest decrease in pore size while retaining high porosity relative to Cu-TPTC. This modification led to a marked improvement in C2H2 adsorption capacity and C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity of Cu-ABTC, along with an extended breakthrough time.


Abstract

Achieving a balance between high selectivity and uptake is a formidable challenge for the purification of acetylene from mixtures with carbon dioxide, particularly when seeking to maximize both C2H2 adsorption capacity and C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity in crystalline porous materials. In this study, leveraging the principles of reticular chemistry, we selected two tetracarboxylate-based linkers and combined them with Cu2+ ions to synthesize two isoreticular dicopper paddle-wheel-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs): Cu-TPTC (terphenyl-3,3’,5,5’-tetracarboxylic acid, H4TPTC) and Cu-ABTC (3,3,5,5-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid, H4ABTC). The structural and sorption analyses revealed that Cu-ABTC, despite having slightly smaller pores due to the strategic replacement of a phenyl ring with an azo group between two tetratopic ligands, maintains high porosity compared to Cu-TPTC. Furthermore, Cu-ABTC outperforms Cu-TPTC in terms of C2H2 adsorption capacity (196 cm3 g−1 at 298 K and 1 bar) and C2H2/CO2 separation selectivity (16.5~5.6). These findings were corroborated by dynamic breakthrough experiments and computational modeling. This research highlights the potential of the isoreticular contraction strategy in enhancing MOFs for sophisticated gas adsorption and separation processes.

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Guest Diffusion Versus Recrystallization in A Single Crystal: Two Growing Mechanisms for Griseofulvin Clathrates
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Exposure of non‐porous griseofulvin (GSF) polymorphs to vapor results in solvated forms via different mechanisms: guest diffusion (Form VI – acetonitrile (ACN) and dichloromethane (DCM)), or dissolution and recrystallization (Form I–DCM), depending on the nature and concentration of the guest.
Abstract Griseofulvin represents a rare case of a close‐packed organic apohost that can clathrate selected volatile guests in a solid‐gas fashion. Inclusion mechanisms and solvent exchange were investigated by a combination of single crystal and powder X‐ray diffraction, coupled to optical microscopy and thermal analyses. In particular, gas diffusion and dissolution/recrystallization are alternatively observed, depending on the host polymorph, as well as the chemical nature of the guest and its physical state.
item.content:encoded:
Exposure of non-porous griseofulvin (GSF) polymorphs to vapor results in solvated forms via different mechanisms: guest diffusion (Form VI – acetonitrile (ACN) and dichloromethane (DCM)), or dissolution and recrystallization (Form I–DCM), depending on the nature and concentration of the guest.


Abstract

Griseofulvin represents a rare case of a close-packed organic apohost that can clathrate selected volatile guests in a solid-gas fashion. Inclusion mechanisms and solvent exchange were investigated by a combination of single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, coupled to optical microscopy and thermal analyses. In particular, gas diffusion and dissolution/recrystallization are alternatively observed, depending on the host polymorph, as well as the chemical nature of the guest and its physical state.

item.dc:title: Guest Diffusion Versus Recrystallization in A Single Crystal: Two Growing Mechanisms for Griseofulvin Clathrates

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Oxydiazomethylation of Alkenes via Photoredox Catalysis
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A general and modular approach for the direct 1,2‐formyloxyl‐diazomethylation of alkenes through visible‐light photoredox catalysis has been developed to assemble γ‐hydroxyl‐α‐diazoesters.
Abstract α‐Diazoesters belong to significantly important carbenoid precursors in synthetic chemistry. Diazomethylation‐based difunctionalization of alkenes is highly valuable but remain nontrivial. Herein, we reported a general and modular approach for the direct 1,2‐oxydiazomethylation of alkenes through visible‐light photoredox catalysis. This process exploits photocatalyzed strategy to convert alkenes to γ‐formyloxyl‐α‐diazoesters using α‐diazo iodonium salts as carbyne precursors, featuring wide substrate tolerance and broad late‐stage diversifications. Mechanistic studies suggest that the formation of γ‐carbocation‐tethered α‐diazoesters plays a crucial role in trapping DMF and H2O to allow for this transformation.
item.content:encoded:
A general and modular approach for the direct 1,2-formyloxyl-diazomethylation of alkenes through visible-light photoredox catalysis has been developed to assemble γ-hydroxyl-α-diazoesters.


Abstract

α-Diazoesters belong to significantly important carbenoid precursors in synthetic chemistry. Diazomethylation-based difunctionalization of alkenes is highly valuable but remain nontrivial. Herein, we reported a general and modular approach for the direct 1,2-oxydiazomethylation of alkenes through visible-light photoredox catalysis. This process exploits photocatalyzed strategy to convert alkenes to γ-formyloxyl-α-diazoesters using α-diazo iodonium salts as carbyne precursors, featuring wide substrate tolerance and broad late-stage diversifications. Mechanistic studies suggest that the formation of γ-carbocation-tethered α-diazoesters plays a crucial role in trapping DMF and H2O to allow for this transformation.
item.dc:creator: Ying Zeng, Xiaochan Zheng, Lixing Shen, Yaru Jing, Shaoyong Chen, Zhongfeng Luo, Zhuofeng Ke, Haisheng Xie, Junshan Liu, Huanfeng Jiang, Wei Zeng

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: S/Se‐Annulated Star‐Shaped Perylene Diimides (PDIs) with Large Two‐Photon Absorption (TPA) Cross‐Section in NIR‐I Region
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Two novel star‐shaped fluorophores named PDI−S and PDI−Se are constructed by S/Se‐fused perylene diimides (PDIs) connected with bicarbazole core. Particularly, PDI−S presents excellent two‐photon absorption cross‐action (δTPA) of 3775 GM excited with 800 nm light, which is the highest value based on PDIs motif in the NIR−I region (700–900 nm).
Abstract Two‐photon absorption (TPA) has attracted growing attention over recent years owing to the wide range of applications in organic nonlinear optical (NLO) materials. The quantitative sensitivity of a two‐photon molecular entity is determined by its TPA cross‐section (δTPA). Perylene diimides (PDIs) are excellent n‐type organic semiconductor materials demonstrating distinguished thermal, optical, and chemical stability. Nonetheless, PDIs‐based scaffolds exhibit poor δTPA in the NIR−I region (700–900 nm) due to the lack of suitable molecular design. Here, two novel star‐shaped PDIs fluorophores, namely PDI−S and PDI−Se, were constructed by four periphery S/Se‐fused PDIs connected with bicarbazole core. PDI−S manifested excellent δTPA of 3775 GM, which are among the highest values reported for PDIs excited in the NIR−I region.
item.content:encoded:
Two novel star-shaped fluorophores named PDI−S and PDI−Se are constructed by S/Se-fused perylene diimides (PDIs) connected with bicarbazole core. Particularly, PDI−S presents excellent two-photon absorption cross-action (δTPA) of 3775 GM excited with 800 nm light, which is the highest value based on PDIs motif in the NIR−I region (700–900 nm).


Abstract

Two-photon absorption (TPA) has attracted growing attention over recent years owing to the wide range of applications in organic nonlinear optical (NLO) materials. The quantitative sensitivity of a two-photon molecular entity is determined by its TPA cross-section (δTPA). Perylene diimides (PDIs) are excellent n-type organic semiconductor materials demonstrating distinguished thermal, optical, and chemical stability. Nonetheless, PDIs-based scaffolds exhibit poor δTPA in the NIR−I region (700–900 nm) due to the lack of suitable molecular design. Here, two novel star-shaped PDIs fluorophores, namely PDI−S and PDI−Se, were constructed by four periphery S/Se-fused PDIs connected with bicarbazole core. PDI−S manifested excellent δTPA of 3775 GM, which are among the highest values reported for PDIs excited in the NIR−I region.
item.dc:creator: Dandan Li, Wenrong Zhao, Gang Li, Yan Xu, Liang Xu, Bo Tang
item.dc:title: S/Se‐Annulated Star‐Shaped Perylene Diimides (PDIs) with Large Two‐Photon Absorption (TPA) Cross‐Section in NIR‐I Region

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Cyclometalated IrIII Complex Possessing Chiral MIC ligand: Regiospecific sp3 C−H Activation and Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of Ketone
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
An iridium(III) complex with a chiral‐MIC ligand where the IrIII undergone an additional Ir−Calkyl bond formation via regiospecific sp3 C−H bond activation, was synthesized. The chiral‐MIC complex was employed in the asymmetric transfer hydrogenation of ketone, and up to 92 % ee was achieved.
Abstract Cyclometalation offers a wide number of organometallic metallacycles showing diverse applications. However, such NHC complexes synthesized via an sp3 C−H bond activation are rare. An iridium(III) complex with a chiral mesoionic N‐heterocyclic carbene (MIC) ligand, where the IrIII forms an additional Ir−C bond via a regiospecific sp3 C−H bond activation at the N‐methylbenzyl wingtip, was synthesized and characterized. To our best knowledge, this represents the first example of cyclometalated iridium(III) complex possessing a chiral MIC donor ligand. The formation of the complex was followed by 2D correlation NMR spectroscopy and the molecular formula mass was evidenced by ESI‐HRMS mass spectrometry. The molecular structure of the IrIII‐MIC complex was unambiguously established by the single crystal XRD data. This cyclometalated IrIII complex was employed in the asymmetric transfer hydrogenation of 4‐bromoacetophenone, and the complex was successful to transfer chirality to the final alcohol molecules (up to 92 % ee).
item.content:encoded:
An iridium(III) complex with a chiral-MIC ligand where the IrIII undergone an additional Ir−Calkyl bond formation via regiospecific sp3 C−H bond activation, was synthesized. The chiral-MIC complex was employed in the asymmetric transfer hydrogenation of ketone, and up to 92 % ee was achieved.


Abstract

Cyclometalation offers a wide number of organometallic metallacycles showing diverse applications. However, such NHC complexes synthesized via an sp3 C−H bond activation are rare. An iridium(III) complex with a chiral mesoionic N-heterocyclic carbene (MIC) ligand, where the IrIII forms an additional Ir−C bond via a regiospecific sp3 C−H bond activation at the N-methylbenzyl wingtip, was synthesized and characterized. To our best knowledge, this represents the first example of cyclometalated iridium(III) complex possessing a chiral MIC donor ligand. The formation of the complex was followed by 2D correlation NMR spectroscopy and the molecular formula mass was evidenced by ESI-HRMS mass spectrometry. The molecular structure of the IrIII-MIC complex was unambiguously established by the single crystal XRD data. This cyclometalated IrIII complex was employed in the asymmetric transfer hydrogenation of 4-bromoacetophenone, and the complex was successful to transfer chirality to the final alcohol molecules (up to 92 % ee).
item.dc:creator: Tarak Nath Saha, Bhaskar Mondal, Rina Mahato, Rajat Naskar, Chinmoy Kumar Hazra, Ramananda Maity
item.dc:title: Cyclometalated IrIII Complex Possessing Chiral MIC ligand: Regiospecific sp3 C−H Activation and Asymmetric Transfer Hydrogenation of Ketone

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Modulating the Supramolecular Assembly of α‐Cyclodextrin and Anderson‐type Polyoxometalate through Covalent Modifications
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
We report here the supramolecular complexion of α‐cyclodextrins (α‐CDs) and the covalently modified Anderson‐type polyoxometalates (POMs). It is demonstrated that the covalent modification mode of the Anderson POMs has a profound influence on the resulting supramolecular complexes, which feature novel organic‐inorganic pseudo‐rotaxane structures and stable chirality transfer in aqueous solutions due to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds.
Abstract A series of unprecedented supramolecular complexes of covalently modified Anderson‐type polyoxometalates (POMs) and α‐cyclodextrins (α‐CDs) have been obtained and characterized in solid state by single‐crystal X‐ray diffraction, and in aqueous solution using various techniques including 1H DOSY NMR, 2D NOESY 1H NMR, isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC), and electrospray ionization time‐of‐flight mass spectroscopy (ESI‐TOF‐MS). It has been demonstrated that the supramolecular assembly process could be modulated by different covalent modification modes of the Anderson POMs, giving rise to a new type of POM/α‐CD complexes featuring organic‐inorganic pseudo‐rotaxane structures, which are in good contrast to those of POM/γ‐CD complexes of poly‐rotaxane structures. Moreover, it is delighted to find that these pseudo‐rotaxanes of POM/α‐CD complexes exhibit stable chirality in aqueous solution, which has not been accomplished in previously reported POM/CD assemblies.
item.content:encoded:
We report here the supramolecular complexion of α-cyclodextrins (α-CDs) and the covalently modified Anderson-type polyoxometalates (POMs). It is demonstrated that the covalent modification mode of the Anderson POMs has a profound influence on the resulting supramolecular complexes, which feature novel organic-inorganic pseudo-rotaxane structures and stable chirality transfer in aqueous solutions due to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds.


Abstract

A series of unprecedented supramolecular complexes of covalently modified Anderson-type polyoxometalates (POMs) and α-cyclodextrins (α-CDs) have been obtained and characterized in solid state by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and in aqueous solution using various techniques including 1H DOSY NMR, 2D NOESY 1H NMR, isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC), and electrospray ionization time-of-flight mass spectroscopy (ESI-TOF-MS). It has been demonstrated that the supramolecular assembly process could be modulated by different covalent modification modes of the Anderson POMs, giving rise to a new type of POM/α-CD complexes featuring organic-inorganic pseudo-rotaxane structures, which are in good contrast to those of POM/γ-CD complexes of poly-rotaxane structures. Moreover, it is delighted to find that these pseudo-rotaxanes of POM/α-CD complexes exhibit stable chirality in aqueous solution, which has not been accomplished in previously reported POM/CD assemblies.
item.dc:creator: Chun‐Yan Liu, Yun‐Jing Mu, Wu‐Ji Chen, Yi‐An Yin, Chang‐Gen Lin, Haralampos N. Miras, Yu‐Fei Song
item.dc:title: Modulating the Supramolecular Assembly of α‐Cyclodextrin and Anderson‐type Polyoxometalate through Covalent Modifications

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Nutation Spectroscopy of a Weakly Interacting Heterobimetallic Spin System
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
An heterobimetallic VIV−CuII complex is synthesized by a modular process involving external coordination sites of a porphyrinato ligand and a PdII linker. Pulsed Electron Paramagnetic Resonance experiments, in particular spin nutation spectroscopy at variable microwave powers or magnetic fields, reveals weak but non‐negligible magnetic interactions and the presence of two transitions of different tipping angles.
Abstract The use of VIV and CuII spins to design weakly coupled and dissymmetric spin systems has been examined. Such systems were synthesized using porphyrin‐based complexes, with external coordination sites allowing for the formation of dimers via a PdII linker ion. Continuous‐wave (CW) Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectroscopy allowed the unequivocal magnetic characterization of the mononuclear precursors VO and Cu. The porphyrin dimer (VO)PdCu presented a broad and overlapped spectrum that was more pronounced than for the previously reported (VO)Pd(VO), hinting at the effect of weak interspin interactions between dissimilar spins. Pulsed EPR experiments on VO, (VO)Pd(VO) and (VO)PdCu samples diluted in a diamagnetic matrix confirmed that this complication is also present in the Field‐Swept Echo‐Detected (FSED) spectra of the heterometallic (VO)PdCu system. Despite the strongly overlapped field‐swept spectra, spin nutation experiments revealed two distinct oscillations in the case of (VO)PdCu, which are assigned to transitions with different spin characters. Remarkably, coherence is retained above liquid nitrogen temperatures for all complexes, in particular up to 295 K for VO and (VO)Pd(VO) and 150 K for (VO)PdCu.
item.content:encoded:

Pulsed Electron Paramagnetic Resonance experiments, in particular spin nutation spectroscopy at variable microwave powers or magnetic fields, reveals weak but non-negligible magnetic interactions and the presence of two transitions of different tipping angles.


Abstract

The use of VIV and CuII spins to design weakly coupled and dissymmetric spin systems has been examined. Such systems were synthesized using porphyrin-based complexes, with external coordination sites allowing for the formation of dimers via a PdII linker ion. Continuous-wave (CW) Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectroscopy allowed the unequivocal magnetic characterization of the mononuclear precursors VO and Cu. The porphyrin dimer (VO)PdCu presented a broad and overlapped spectrum that was more pronounced than for the previously reported (VO)Pd(VO), hinting at the effect of weak interspin interactions between dissimilar spins. Pulsed EPR experiments on VO, (VO)Pd(VO) and (VO)PdCu samples diluted in a diamagnetic matrix confirmed that this complication is also present in the Field-Swept Echo-Detected (FSED) spectra of the heterometallic (VO)PdCu system. Despite the strongly overlapped field-swept spectra, spin nutation experiments revealed two distinct oscillations in the case of (VO)PdCu, which are assigned to transitions with different spin characters. Remarkably, coherence is retained above liquid nitrogen temperatures for all complexes, in particular up to 295 K for VO and (VO)Pd(VO) and 150 K for (VO)PdCu.
item.dc:creator: Jordan L. Appleton, Nolwenn Le Breton, Sylvie Choua, Romain Ruppert, Athanassios K. Boudalis
item.dc:title: Nutation Spectroscopy of a Weakly Interacting Heterobimetallic Spin System

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Enhanced Efficiency and Intrinsic Stability of Wide‐Bandgap Perovskite Solar Cells Through Dimethylamine‐Based Cation Engineering
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The incorporation of the DMA cation into triple cation perovskites significantly altered the crystal structure and grain growth of the perovskite films. This modification inhibited halide segregation and enhanced carrier mobility. As a result, a remarkable power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 21.9 % was achieved for wide‐bandgap PSCs with a bandgap of 1.68 eV. Furthermore, the stability of PSCs based on DMA‐doped perovskite was substantially improved. After exposure to ambient air for 1500 hours, the unencapsulated device retained an impressive 80.6 % of its initial efficiency. This demonstrates the great potential of DMA doping for developing stable and efficient wide‐bandgap PSCs.
Abstract High efficiency and stable wide‐bandgap (WBG) perovskite solar cells (PSCs) are crucial for the development of perovskite‐based tandem solar cells. However, the efficiency and stability of WBG PSCs are compromised by significant phase segregation and surface defects. In this study, we introduce a cation engineering strategy for WBG perovskite, employing a two‐step sequential method that incorporates dimethylamine hydroiodide (DMAI) into the lead halide complex during the initial step. The addition of DMAI modifies the crystal structure and grain growth of the perovskite film, leading to improved crystal quality, reduced photo‐induced halide segregation, decreased defect density, and enhanced charge carrier mobility. Consequently, we achieved a champion power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 21.9 % for 1.68 eV WBG PSCs. Furthermore, the stability of PSCs based on DMA‐doped perovskite was significantly improved. After 1500 hours of exposure to ambient air, the unencapsulated device retained an impressive 80.6 % of its initial efficiency. This result highlights the substantial potential for stable and efficient WBG PSCs.
item.content:encoded:
The incorporation of the DMA cation into triple cation perovskites significantly altered the crystal structure and grain growth of the perovskite films. This modification inhibited halide segregation and enhanced carrier mobility. As a result, a remarkable power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 21.9 % was achieved for wide-bandgap PSCs with a bandgap of 1.68 eV. Furthermore, the stability of PSCs based on DMA-doped perovskite was substantially improved. After exposure to ambient air for 1500 hours, the unencapsulated device retained an impressive 80.6 % of its initial efficiency. This demonstrates the great potential of DMA doping for developing stable and efficient wide-bandgap PSCs.


Abstract

High efficiency and stable wide-bandgap (WBG) perovskite solar cells (PSCs) are crucial for the development of perovskite-based tandem solar cells. However, the efficiency and stability of WBG PSCs are compromised by significant phase segregation and surface defects. In this study, we introduce a cation engineering strategy for WBG perovskite, employing a two-step sequential method that incorporates dimethylamine hydroiodide (DMAI) into the lead halide complex during the initial step. The addition of DMAI modifies the crystal structure and grain growth of the perovskite film, leading to improved crystal quality, reduced photo-induced halide segregation, decreased defect density, and enhanced charge carrier mobility. Consequently, we achieved a champion power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 21.9 % for 1.68 eV WBG PSCs. Furthermore, the stability of PSCs based on DMA-doped perovskite was significantly improved. After 1500 hours of exposure to ambient air, the unencapsulated device retained an impressive 80.6 % of its initial efficiency. This result highlights the substantial potential for stable and efficient WBG PSCs.
item.dc:creator: Tianhe Dong, Li Tan, Ze Li, Jiashun Li, Hongyu Li, Jing Liao, Xu Chen, Wenfeng Zhang, Haijin Li
item.dc:title: Enhanced Efficiency and Intrinsic Stability of Wide‐Bandgap Perovskite Solar Cells Through Dimethylamine‐Based Cation Engineering

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Unlocking the Chemical and Structural Complexity of Aluminum Hydroxy Acetates: from Commodity Chemicals to Porous Materials
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A high‐throughput investigation involving more than 330 reactions in the system Al3+/CH3COOH/NaOH/H2O permitted the elucidation of the synthesis‐structure relationship and allowed us to shed light on the structural chemistry and porosity of aluminum acetates for the first time. The robust synthesis procedures permitted scale‐up under mild reaction conditions in high yields.
Abstract Aluminum acetates have been in use for more than a century, but despite their widespread commercial applications, essential scientific knowledge of their synthesis‐structure‐property relationships is lacking. High‐throughput screening, followed by fine tuning and extensive optimization of reaction conditions using Al3+, OH− and CH3COO− ions, has unraveled their complex synthetic chemistry, yielding for the first time the four phase pure products Al(OH)(O2CCH3)2 ⋅ x H2O (x=0, 2) (1A and CAU‐65, 1B), Al3O(HO2CCH3)(O2CCH3)7 (2), and the porous aluminum salt [Al24(OH)56(CH3COO)12](OH)4 (CAU‐55‐OH, 3). Structure determination by electron and X‐ray diffraction was carried out and the data suggested porosity for 1B and 3, which was confirmed by physisorption experiments. Even the scale‐up to the 10 L scale was accomplished for 1A, 1B and 3 with yields of up to 1.1 kg (99 %). This study of a seemingly simple chemical system provides important information on both fundamental inorganic chemistry and porous materials.
item.content:encoded:
A high-throughput investigation involving more than 330 reactions in the system Al3+/CH3COOH/NaOH/H2O permitted the elucidation of the synthesis-structure relationship and allowed us to shed light on the structural chemistry and porosity of aluminum acetates for the first time. The robust synthesis procedures permitted scale-up under mild reaction conditions in high yields.


Abstract

Aluminum acetates have been in use for more than a century, but despite their widespread commercial applications, essential scientific knowledge of their synthesis-structure-property relationships is lacking. High-throughput screening, followed by fine tuning and extensive optimization of reaction conditions using Al3+, OH− and CH3COO− ions, has unraveled their complex synthetic chemistry, yielding for the first time the four phase pure products Al(OH)(O2CCH3)2 ⋅ x H2O (x=0, 2) (1A and CAU-65, 1B), Al3O(HO2CCH3)(O2CCH3)7 (2), and the porous aluminum salt [Al24(OH)56(CH3COO)12](OH)4 (CAU-55-OH, 3). Structure determination by electron and X-ray diffraction was carried out and the data suggested porosity for 1B and 3, which was confirmed by physisorption experiments. Even the scale-up to the 10 L scale was accomplished for 1A, 1B and 3 with yields of up to 1.1 kg (99 %). This study of a seemingly simple chemical system provides important information on both fundamental inorganic chemistry and porous materials.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Achenbach, Lena‐Marie Liedtke, Christian Näther, Erik Svensson Grape, A. Ken Inge, Norbert Stock
item.dc:title: Unlocking the Chemical and Structural Complexity of Aluminum Hydroxy Acetates: from Commodity Chemicals to Porous Materials

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Asymmetric Organocatalysed Synthesis of (R)‐Mandelic Acid Esters and α‐Alkoxy Derivatives from Commercial Sources
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A first catalytic one‐pot chemical synthesis of optically active (R)‐mandelic acids, esters and α‐alkoxy ester derivatives has been developed. The value‐added final compounds have been obtained in high overall yield (26–94 %) and enantioselectivity (up to 97 % ee), through a straightforward route from commercially and widely available reagents, including aldehydes, water, alcohols and the organocatalyst.
Abstract Optically active mandelic acid esters represent a highly valuable class of building blocks in organic synthesis and recurrent motifs embedded in bioactive compounds and drugs. Herein, we provide an enantioselective one‐pot synthesis based on Knoevenagel condensation/asymmetric epoxidation/domino ring‐opening hydrolysis (DROH) sequence to the crude mandelic acids, which underwent a final esterification step to (R)‐methyl mandelates. These products have been obtained in good to high overall yield and enantioselectivity, using commercially and widely available reagents and catalyst including aldehydes, phenylsulfonyl acetonitrile, cumyl hydroperoxide, water and an epi‐quinine‐derived urea as the organocatalyst. Moreover, the versatility of the process has been demonstrated to prepare the corresponding α‐alkoxy esters in highly enantioselective manner, when using primary alcohols in a domino ring‐opening esterification (DROE) step. This system is a first example of non‐enzymatic catalytic one‐pot protocol which allows a straightforward asymmetric synthesis of highly valuable mandelic acid derivatives from aldehyde feedstocks.
item.content:encoded:
A first catalytic one-pot chemical synthesis of optically active (R)-mandelic acids, esters and α-alkoxy ester derivatives has been developed. The value-added final compounds have been obtained in high overall yield (26–94 %) and enantioselectivity (up to 97 % ee), through a straightforward route from commercially and widely available reagents, including aldehydes, water, alcohols and the organocatalyst.


Abstract

Optically active mandelic acid esters represent a highly valuable class of building blocks in organic synthesis and recurrent motifs embedded in bioactive compounds and drugs. Herein, we provide an enantioselective one-pot synthesis based on Knoevenagel condensation/asymmetric epoxidation/domino ring-opening hydrolysis (DROH) sequence to the crude mandelic acids, which underwent a final esterification step to (R)-methyl mandelates. These products have been obtained in good to high overall yield and enantioselectivity, using commercially and widely available reagents and catalyst including aldehydes, phenylsulfonyl acetonitrile, cumyl hydroperoxide, water and an epi-quinine-derived urea as the organocatalyst. Moreover, the versatility of the process has been demonstrated to prepare the corresponding α-alkoxy esters in highly enantioselective manner, when using primary alcohols in a domino ring-opening esterification (DROE) step. This system is a first example of non-enzymatic catalytic one-pot protocol which allows a straightforward asymmetric synthesis of highly valuable mandelic acid derivatives from aldehyde feedstocks.
item.dc:creator: Vincenzo Battaglia, Sara Meninno, Alessandra Lattanzi
item.dc:title: Asymmetric Organocatalysed Synthesis of (R)‐Mandelic Acid Esters and α‐Alkoxy Derivatives from Commercial Sources

item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Self‐Assembly of Metallo‐Supramolecular Amphiphiles based on Azadipyrromethenes: Consecutive Pathways to Nanodiscs and Nanosheets
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Consecutive self‐assembly pathways were revealed for a metallo‐supramolecular amphiphilic dye based on azadipyrromethenes, which led to the first formation of kinetic‐controlled, nanodisc‐shaped Agg. I and the further spontaneous transformation from Agg. I to the thermodynamically more stable Agg. II with a morphology of nanosheet.
Abstract A new class of metallo‐supramolecular amphiphilic dyes 1 a, b was constructed by using two azadipyrromethene units which were respectively modified with two hydrophobic alkyl and two hydrophilic oligo(ethylene glycol) chains. The spectroscopic and morphological studies revealed the consecutive self‐assembly pathways of 1 a in EtOH/H2O mixed solvent. The monomers of 1 a firstly aggregated into the kinetic‐controlled, nanodisc‐shaped Agg. I upon cooling and the latter spontaneously transformed into the thermodynamically more stable Agg. II with a nanosheet morphology. While the non‐fluorescent Agg. I displayed a broad absorption band (λmax=615 nm), the Agg. II displayed a more intensive and narrowed J‐band (λmax=693 nm) and a fluorescence band with a maximum at 760 nm (Φfl=0.1), which could be ascribed to the J‐aggregation induced emission enhancement. The kinetics of Agg. I to Agg. II transformation was further modulated by seed‐initiated supramolecular polymerization with various ratios of Seedagg.II, in which the transformation rate was significantly increased by ca. 2 orders of magnitude compared to the spontaneous process. The supramolecular amphiphile 1 b bearing longer hydrophilic chains formed only one type aggregate, which exhibited spectroscopic and morphological properties that were highly comparable with that of Agg. I.
item.content:encoded:
Consecutive self-assembly pathways were revealed for a metallo-supramolecular amphiphilic dye based on azadipyrromethenes, which led to the first formation of kinetic-controlled, nanodisc-shaped Agg. I and the further spontaneous transformation from Agg. I to the thermodynamically more stable Agg. II with a morphology of nanosheet.


Abstract

A new class of metallo-supramolecular amphiphilic dyes 1 a, b was constructed by using two azadipyrromethene units which were respectively modified with two hydrophobic alkyl and two hydrophilic oligo(ethylene glycol) chains. The spectroscopic and morphological studies revealed the consecutive self-assembly pathways of 1 a in EtOH/H2O mixed solvent. The monomers of 1 a firstly aggregated into the kinetic-controlled, nanodisc-shaped Agg. I upon cooling and the latter spontaneously transformed into the thermodynamically more stable Agg. II with a nanosheet morphology. While the non-fluorescent Agg. I displayed a broad absorption band (λ max=615 nm), the Agg. II displayed a more intensive and narrowed J-band (λ max=693 nm) and a fluorescence band with a maximum at 760 nm (Φ fl=0.1), which could be ascribed to the J-aggregation induced emission enhancement. The kinetics of Agg. I to Agg. II transformation was further modulated by seed-initiated supramolecular polymerization with various ratios of Seedagg.II , in which the transformation rate was significantly increased by ca. 2 orders of magnitude compared to the spontaneous process. The supramolecular amphiphile 1 b bearing longer hydrophilic chains formed only one type aggregate, which exhibited spectroscopic and morphological properties that were highly comparable with that of Agg. I.

item.dc:title: Self‐Assembly of Metallo‐Supramolecular Amphiphiles based on Azadipyrromethenes: Consecutive Pathways to Nanodiscs and Nanosheets

item.title: Front Cover: Exploring the Role of Titanate Perovskites in the Oxidation of Amines via Photocatalysis (Chem. Eur. J. 4/2025)
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description: Photocatalysis offers a sustainable approach to chemical synthesis by using light energy to drive selective reactions. This study introduces titanate perovskites as promising photocatalysts that demonstrate selective efficiency in converting benzylamine to N‐benzylidenebenzylamine under mild conditions. Among the tested materials, CaTiO3 stands out with superior performance, underscoring its potential as an effective catalyst for light‐driven chemical transformations. More information can be found in the Research Article by J. C. Lopes, J. L. Faria and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202402422).

item.title: Cover Feature: Asymmetric Organocatalysed Synthesis of (R)‐Mandelic Acid Esters and α‐Alkoxy Derivatives from Commercial Sources (Chem. Eur. J. 4/2025)
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description: The Cover Feature depicts an asymmetric one‐pot synthesis of mandelic acid derivatives. A bifunctional organocatalyst selectively promotes two reactions leading to enantioenriched 1‐cyano‐1‐phenylsulfonyl epoxides, which undergo water‐mediated ring‐opening and then hydrolysis in a cascade process, yielding the products with high efficiency and enantioselectivity. The cover art shows the synthetic sequence with intermediates formed from atop a waterfall, highlighting the role of water in crucial steps. More information can be found in the Research Article by A. Lattanzi and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/chem.202403769).

The cover art shows the synthetic sequence with intermediates formed from atop a waterfall, highlighting the role of water in crucial steps. item.dc:description: The commercial importance and industrial‐scale production of aluminum acetates for more than a century contrasts with our limited understanding of their synthesis, composition, and crystal structures. item.source: Wiley: Chemistry – A European Journal: Table of Contents
item.title: Stimuli‐Responsive Polymers for Tubal Actuators
item.description: Chemistry – A European Journal, Volume 31, Issue 4, January 17, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Tubal actuators provide certain advantages compared to solid actuators, including the capability to detect and regulate fluid flow. Consequently, they exhibit great potential in various applications, including blood vessel removal, controlled delivery systems, soft actuation, and robotics. The recent work on liquid crystal elastomer tubal actuators, hydrogel tubal actuators, and shape memory plastic tubal actuators is introduced, emphasizing their potentials in various biomedical and engineering applications.
Abstract Stimuli‐responsive polymers for tubal actuators have garnered significant attention due to their potential applications in soft robotics, artificial blood vessels, controlled liquid transportation, and microchemical reactors. This perspective emphasizes the advantages, response mechanisms, and fundamental design principles of stimuli‐responsive polymers for tubal actuators. It also addresses the biological and engineering applications, current challenges, and future prospects of stimuli‐responsive polymers for tubal actuators. The discussion categorizes stimuli‐responsive polymers for tubal actuators based on various properties, including liquid crystal elastomer actuators, hydrogel actuators, and shape memory polymer actuators. The subsequent sections focuses on the structural features, design principles, and biological applications of stimuli‐responsive polymers for tubal actuator, elucidating their potential interrelationships. The molecular architectures and design principles are intricately linked to the stimuli‐responsive mechanisms. Finally, this perspective outlines the challenges faced by stimuli‐responsive polymers for tubal actuators. This article aims to facilitate broader applications of stimuli‐responsive polymers for tubal actuators, thereby promoting progress across multiple fields.

The recent work on liquid crystal elastomer tubal actuators, hydrogel tubal actuators, and shape memory plastic tubal actuators is introduced, emphasizing their potentials in various biomedical and engineering applications.


Abstract

Stimuli-responsive polymers for tubal actuators have garnered significant attention due to their potential applications in soft robotics, artificial blood vessels, controlled liquid transportation, and microchemical reactors. This perspective emphasizes the advantages, response mechanisms, and fundamental design principles of stimuli-responsive polymers for tubal actuators. It also addresses the biological and engineering applications, current challenges, and future prospects of stimuli-responsive polymers for tubal actuators. The discussion categorizes stimuli-responsive polymers for tubal actuators based on various properties, including liquid crystal elastomer actuators, hydrogel actuators, and shape memory polymer actuators. The subsequent sections focuses on the structural features, design principles, and biological applications of stimuli-responsive polymers for tubal actuator, elucidating their potential interrelationships. The molecular architectures and design principles are intricately linked to the stimuli-responsive mechanisms. Finally, this perspective outlines the challenges faced by stimuli-responsive polymers for tubal actuators. This article aims to facilitate broader applications of stimuli-responsive polymers for tubal actuators, thereby promoting progress across multiple fields.
